title: 103_s1899
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia is recognized for its unspoiled areas, excellent water quality, historic landscapes, and recreational opportunities. It connects national historic districts and landmarks, offering scenic vistas and open spaces for visitors. The Augusta Canal in Georgia offers undeveloped recreational opportunities and represents the development of the cotton textile industry in the South. It played a significant role in the transformation of the area's economy and is home to various historical sites related to American Revolution, Civil War, and diverse ethnic groups. Despite efforts from various entities, the area's cultural, historical, and recreational resources have not reached their full potential and may need assistance from the Federal Government to prevent loss. The Augusta Canal National Historic Landmark is considered threatened and a priority for protection by the Secretary of the Interior. Local, regional, and State agencies, businesses, and private citizens are eager to work together to preserve and enhance the resources of the area. The purpose of this Act is to establish a cooperative management framework for the Augusta Canal in Georgia to preserve its significant features while promoting economic development. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area boundaries will be defined as part of this initiative. Establishment of Augusta Canal National Heritage Area in Georgia and South Carolina, including lands commonly known as Augusta Canal. Boundaries defined in Augusta Canal Master Plan. Secretary of the Interior to publish detailed description and map of boundaries. Augusta Canal Commission established. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary from various recommendations. The Commission will elect a chairman from its members, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Augusta Canal Commission must prepare a management plan for the Heritage Area within a year of this Act's enactment. The plan should integrate existing Federal, State, and local plans, including the Augusta Canal Master Plan, to protect and enhance the area's cultural, natural, scenic, and recreational resources. The Secretary can offer technical and financial assistance for plan preparation, and must approve or disapprove the plan within 180 days based on specific criteria. The Secretary will consider local support, economic impact, partnership potential, property rights, and compliance with the plan when approving a management plan. If the plan is disapproved, the Augusta Canal Commission will be notified in writing with reasons for the decision. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 180 days. The Secretary will implement the approved plan in cooperation with the Commission and may enter into cooperative agreements with the State of Georgia. The Secretary can enter into cooperative agreements with Georgia, political subdivisions, Augusta Canal Commission, or individuals to implement the management plan. Economic development efforts should align with the goals of the Augusta Canal Master Plan. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS. This Act does not impose stricter regulations on the Heritage Area than those in place before its establishment. No Federal agency can introduce more stringent regulations solely due to the Heritage Area's creation. SEC. 7. DUTIES OF OTHER FEDERAL ENTITIES. Federal entities conducting activities in the Heritage Area must consult, cooperate, and coordinate with the Secretary and Augusta Canal Commission to ensure no adverse effects. Appropriations are authorized as needed for this Act.
